para.paratext: Any person who is at least 18 years of age may serve a subpoena.[1] The subpoena may be served in person, by registered or certified mail, or upon a party's counsel of record. If served by mail, the return receipt is prima facie proof of service. It is desirable to subpoena the opposing party if counsel expects to examine him. Service upon the witness shall not be fewer than 24 hours before the witness' appearance is required.[2]
Under former O.C.G.A. § 24-10-22, a judge could quash or stay a subpoena at an ex parte hearing.[3] Due to the similarity of the new O.C.G.A. § 24-13-21, this should still be good law.

In Eubanks v. Brooks, 139 Ga. App. 166, 227 S.E.2d 923 (1976), the witness was served with a subpoena about 7:00 p.m. which required her to appear in court at 9:00 a.m. the next morning. She went to the courthouse at 8:30 a.m. and was advised that the subpoena was invalid, so she left. The court held her in contempt, but was reversed on appeal because the trial judge could extend the length of notice required for service to more than 24 hours, but could not reduce it to fewer than 24 hours.

In Piper v. Piper, 139 Ga. App. 19, 227 S.E.2d 842 (1976), the court held that the judge could grant a motion to quash or stay a subpoena at an ex parte hearing under former O.C.G.A. 24-10-22, which applied to subpoenas for production of documentary evidence.
